Award.AwardTitle: Nanoparticle Interactions and Nanoscale Transport in Polyelectrolyte Brushes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanoparticles come in a variety of sizes, shapes, chemistries, and functionalities, including folded proteins, viruses, and quantum dots. This project will research the motion of individual nanoparticles in complex environments. Most previous studies of nanoparticle motion have been limited to studies of ensembles of particles or particles in homogeneous environments, and these studies provide a valuable foundation upon which to build. Recent advances in imaging methods and data processing methods enable the study of nanoparticles in heterogeneous environments one particle at a time. A new imaging method provides improved spatial and temporal resolution that detects biomolecules at interface, and the investigators will apply this advanced imaging method to the study of nanoparticle motion at interfaces, particularly interfaces with various functionalities. These studies and fundamental understanding will inform advanced strategies for separating natural or synthetic nanoparticles based on size, shape, or charge. The investigators will mentor undergraduate researchers, engage with public outreach events across Philadelphia, and partner with a program to bring the science laboratory to underserved high school students.

Nanoparticles come in a variety of sizes, shapes, chemistries, and functionalities, ranging from folded proteins, viruses, and quantum dots. Because nanoparticles at interfaces underpin a broad and expanding range of applications including nanoscale filtering and detection, this project will research the motion of individual nanoparticles in complex local environments. Most previous studies of nanoparticle motion have been limited to studies of ensembles of particles or particles in homogeneous environments, and these studies provide a valuable foundation upon which to build. Recent advances in imaging methods and data processing methods enable the study of nanoparticles in heterogeneous environments one particle at a time. Interferometric scattering microscopy provides exceptional spatial and temporal resolution and was originally developed to image biomolecules at interfaces. This project will use this advanced method to study nanoparticle motion at interfaces, particularly interfaces with various functionalities, and under applied electric fields. These studies and fundamental understanding will inform advanced strategies for separating natural or synthetic nanoparticles based on size, shape, or charge by designing interfaces that selectively trap nanoparticles. This new understanding will also provide strategies for producing higher quality nanoparticle products with more uniform characteristics. Differentiating mechanisms of nanoparticle dynamics can also lead to advanced sensing applications. PIs Winey and Composto will mentor undergraduate researchers, engage with public outreach events across Philadelphia, and partner with a program to bring the science laboratory to underserved high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded significant advances in understanding nanoparticle motion in various environments. Foundational knowledge about how nanoparticles move could be applied to a variety of existing and emerging technologies including purification after nanoparticle synthesis, controlled delivery on nano-encapsulated drugs, and membranes designed to selectively remove various nanoparticles and nanoscale biomolecules. The funding was also essential for educating students in the field of chemical engineering and materials science.

We studied nanoparticle mobility in water-based gels. Notably, we found that the nanoparticle shape impacts nanoparticle mobility. While spherical quantum dots (QDs) have greater mobility than quantum rods (QRs) before gelation, the QRs exhibit enhanced mobility as the hydrogel develops. The study also revealed that nanoscale defects in hydrogels increase QD mobility, indicating that nanoparticle size influences their interaction with network structures. Additionally, machine learning techniques like Mask R-CNN significantly improved particle detection in interferometric scattering microscopy (ISCAT) images, enhancing accuracy in complex environments.

We also studied nanoparticle mobility is solvent-free polymer nanocomposites and demonstrated the presence of two recently hypothesized mechanisms of nanoparticle motion and explored the limitations of these mechanisms in crowded systems. Importantly, we demonstrated the novel use of time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy (TOF-SIMS) to measure nanoparticle and polymer diffusion in polymer melts. Relative to previously available experimental methods for measuring these fundamental parameters, TOF-SIMS is more readily available and provides future opportunities to study diffusion in a wider variety of systems. After establishing the method by demonstrating consistency with other measurements of polymer and nanoparticle diffusion, we demonstrated that strong interactions between the polymer and nanoparticle increase the effective size of the nanoparticle, while this mechanism is insufficient to describe systems with weaker interactions. By identifying the transition from the core-shell mechanism to the vehicular mechanism, we measured the residence time of the bound polymer on the nanoparticle. Next, we extended this work to probe nanoparticle diffusion into crowded nanoparticle systems and found unexpectedly fast nanoparticle diffusion that we associate with the residence time measured in dilute systems.

Finally, we designed pH-responsive surface-attached polymers to selectively adsorb nanoparticles based on size. We assembled block copolymers onto a surface with the hydrophilic block exposed to the nanoparticle solution. To control nanoparticle adsorption, we modulated the nature of the polymer-nanoparticle interactions by using the salt concentration of the nanoparticle solution. In addition, we chemically modified the block copolymers to have a permanent charge, as an additional feature to tune nanoparticle adsorption using electrostatic interactions.

This grant supported the publication of 11 scientific papers, numerous contributed and invited talks, and the education and training of 1 post-doctoral researcher, 5 doctoral student, and 2 undergraduates. This grant also supported a variety of outreach and educational activities to promote scientific literacy in our local community.

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2024
Modified by: Karen I Winey
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This grant funded significant advances in understanding nanoparticle motion in various environments. Foundational knowledge about how nanoparticles move could be applied to a variety of existing and emerging technologies including purification after nanoparticle synthesis, controlled delivery on nano-encapsulated drugs, and membranes designed to selectively remove various nanoparticles and nanoscale biomolecules. The funding was also essential for educating students in the field of chemical engineering and materials science. We studied nanoparticle mobility in water-based gels. Notably, we found that the nanoparticle shape impacts nanoparticle mobility. While spherical quantum dots (QDs) have greater mobility than quantum rods (QRs) before gelation, the QRs exhibit enhanced mobility as the hydrogel develops. The study also revealed that nanoscale defects in hydrogels increase QD mobility, indicating that nanoparticle size influences their interaction with network structures. Additionally, machine learning techniques like Mask R-CNN significantly improved particle detection in interferometric scattering microscopy (ISCAT) images, enhancing accuracy in complex environments. We also studied nanoparticle mobility is solvent-free polymer nanocomposites and demonstrated the presence of two recently hypothesized mechanisms of nanoparticle motion and explored the limitations of these mechanisms in crowded systems. Importantly, we demonstrated the novel use of time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy (TOF-SIMS) to measure nanoparticle and polymer diffusion in polymer melts. Finally, we designed pH-responsive surface-attached polymers to selectively adsorb nanoparticles based on size. We assembled block copolymers onto a surface with the hydrophilic block exposed to the nanoparticle solution. To control nanoparticle adsorption, we modulated the nature of the polymer-nanoparticle interactions by using the salt concentration of the nanoparticle solution. In addition, we chemically modified the block copolymers to have a permanent charge, as an additional feature to tune nanoparticle adsorption using electrostatic interactions. This grant supported the publication of 11 scientific papers, numerous contributed and invited talks, and the education and training of 1 post-doctoral researcher, 5 doctoral student, and 2 undergraduates. This grant also supported a variety of outreach and educational activities to promote scientific literacy in our local community. Last Modified: 11/13/2024 Submitted by: KarenIWiney
